Tobiasz Czopowicz for the NA61/SHINE Collaboration
body_text.section: NA61/SHINE Physics Program -First Results and Future Plans

body_text.text: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
The NA61/SHINE experiment aims to discover the critical point of strongly interacting matter and study properties of the onset of deconfinement.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: These goals are to be achieved by performing a two-dimensional phase diagram (T − μ B ) scan -measurements of hadron production as a function of collision energy and system size.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: With its large acceptance and good particle identification NA61/SHINE also performs detailed and precise particle production measurements for the T2K, Pierre Auger Observatory and KASCADE-Grande experiments.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: This contribution summarizes current status and future plans as well as presents the first physics results of the NA61/SHINE experiment.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The NA61/SHINE physics goals NA61/SHINE (SPS Heavy Ion and Neutrino Experiment)
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: 1) is a fixed-target experiment located in the North Area of the Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) accelerator facility at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva, Switzerland.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: It is the successor of the NA49 experiment,
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: 2) which was operating in 1994 -2002.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The NA61/SHINE collaboration consists of 140 physicists from 28 institutes in 13 countries.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: NA61/SHINE physics goals are:
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: • search for the critical point of strongly interacting matter,
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: • detailed study of the onset of deconfinement,
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: • study high p T hadrons in p+p and p+Pb interactions, • perform reference measurements for neutrino physics (the T2K experiment) by measuring the hadron production of the T2K target exposed to the proton beam at 31A GeV/c, 3), 4) • perform reference measurements for cosmic-ray physics (KASCADE-Grande and Pierre Auger Observatory experiments) by measuring p+C and π+C interactions.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: 6) In order to search for the critical point and study the properties of the onset of deconfinement, NA61/SHINE performs a two-dimensional phase diagram scan.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: It measures hadron production in various collisions (p+p, Be+Be, Ar+Ca, Xe+La) at various beam energies (13A, 20A, 30A, 40A, 80A and 158A GeV).
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: 7) These new data, together with Pb+Pb reactions recorded by NA49 will allow to cover the region, where the critical point is expected (Fig. 1).
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: According to lattice calculations T CP = 162 ± 2 MeV and μ CP B = 360 ± 40 MeV.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: 8) NA61/SHINE will search for the onset of "kink, horn, step" 9), 10) signatures in light nuclei and a maximum of fluctuation signals for systems freezing-out close to the critical point.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The NA61/SHINE detector is a large acceptance hadron spectrometer.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The main components of the current detector were constructed and successfully used by NA49.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The experimental set-up is shown in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The main tracking devices are four large volume Time Projection Chambers (TPC) inherited from NA49.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: Two of them are located in the magnetic field, two others are positioned downstream of the magnets symmetrically to the beam line.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: These detectors allow reconstruction of over 1000 tracks in a single Pb+Pb interaction.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The most downstream detector (the Projectile Spectator Detector, mounted in 2011) is designed to measure the number of non-interacting nucleons from the projectile nuclei on event-by-event basis.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: High resolution of measurement of the total energy of the projectile spectators (σ(E)/E < 55%/ √ E) in a very broad energy range should lead to a low uncertainty in the determination of the number of interacting nucleons even for peripheral collisions of heavy nuclei at low energies.

body_text.text: During the first two years of running over 120 million events have been collected (including data for neutrino and cosmic-ray physics).

body_text.text: Also the first steps of the phase diagram scan were accomplished: p+p data at six energies were collected (Fig. 1).

body_text.text: In 2011 first ion run -partial energy scan with Be+Be collisions -took place.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland

body_text.text: The program will be completed by Ar+Ca and Xe+La energy scans in 2014 and 2015, respectively.
body_text.section: Faculty of Physics, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
